G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, which grants the Superior Court original jurisdiction over civil actions where the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County under G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the tort occurred in Boston, Massachusetts.

Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every motorist owes a duty to exercise reasonable care in the operation of a motor vehicle to avoid foreseeable harm to others on the roadway, including bicyclists.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a social host owes a duty in negligence regarding injuries caused by an intoxicated guest; it analyzes when a host has a duty based on control of the liquor supply. It does not purport to define the general duty of care owed by motorists in operating motor vehicles, nor does it mention bicyclists or roadway users generally. Thus it does not provide authority for the broad proposition about every motorist’s duty to exercise reasonable care toward others on the roadway, including bicyclists.
Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff claims that these circumstances impose a common law duty in negligence on the defendant for the protection of travelers on the highways. The question whether the defendant owed a duty to travelers who might be injured by the negligent driving of an intoxicated guest who had been at the defendant's party presents 'a question of law [which is] to be determined by reference to existing social values and customs and appropriate social policy.'"

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care when parking and exiting his vehicle, including the duty to ensure that no bicyclist or other road user would be endangered by opening his door.

Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care when parking and exiting his vehicle, including the duty to ensure that no bicyclist or other road user would be endangered by opening his door.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.support_reasoning: The case is a Massachusetts premises-liability decision about the duty owed by landowners to adult trespassers. It does not involve motor vehicles, parking, opening car doors, or duties owed by drivers to bicyclists or other road users. Its holding concerns a landowner’s limited duty (refrain from wilful, wanton, or reckless conduct) toward adult trespassers, so it does not support a proposition about reasonable care when exiting a vehicle in traffic.
Schofield v. Merrill, 386 Mass. 244 (198.relevant_excerpt: "The question before us is whether we should abolish our common law rule that a landowner is not liable to an adult trespasser for injuries resulting from the landowner's negligence. We conclude that the rule should be retained, and we affirm the judgment of the Superior Court.... The traditional rule in this Commonwealth is that a trespasser is entitled to no greater duty of care from one with a right of control over land... than that he refrain from wilful, wanton or reckless disregard for the trespasser's safety."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60B.proposition: Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:

Lancaster v. Norfolk & Dedham Mut. Fire.raw_text: Lancaster v. Norfolk & Dedham Mut. Fire Ins. Co., 440 Mass. 14 (2003)
Lancaster v. Norfolk & Dedham Mut. Fire.proposition: Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:
Lancaster v. Norfolk & Dedham Mut. Fire.support_reasoning: The quoted text is a partial dissent/concurrence, not the majority rule of the case. It advocates for expanding the definition of a decedent’s “estate” for elective share purposes to include certain trust assets, but explicitly recognizes this would be a prospective change and is not the law applied to the plaintiff’s claim. Because the court’s controlling opinion rejects this expansion, Lancaster (through this Greaney concurrence/dissent) does not establish binding Massachusetts authority imposing the type of liability suggested in the proposition.
Lancaster v. Norfolk & Dedham Mut. Fire.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the court’s conclusion that the plaintiff cannot recover in this case on the theories argued. I favor adopting, however, the principles expressed in § 9.1(c) of the Restatement (Third) of Property… If the protection contemplated by the statutory elective share is to have any practical significance… a deceased’s ‘estate’ cannot be limited solely to the probate estate… I would apply such a rule on a prospective basis only, to any trust created or amended after the date of this opinion.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition is that relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing defendant’s liability include this case. Jupin squarely holds that a homeowner who allows guns to be stored in her home and grants unsupervised access to someone known to be violent and mentally unstable owes a duty of reasonable care to foreseeable victims, including a police officer later shot with one of those guns. That makes Jupin a directly supportive Massachusetts authority for imposing negligence-based liability on such a defendant.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.raw_text: Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (1994)
Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.proposition: Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:
Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Davis v. Allard deals with (1) the driver Allard’s negligence and use of his prior criminal admissions, and (2) the premises operator Wonderland’s potential duty and liability for pedestrian safety and for acts of police officers working details. The proposition as stated—"Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:"—is incomplete and does not identify a specific legal rule (e.g., duty of a premises owner, vicarious liability, etc.). While the case does discuss and partly affirm liability (against Allard and potentially against Wonderland on retrial), without a defined proposition about what kind of "Defendant’s liability" is at issue, it cannot be said clearly that this case supports the unspecified proposition.
Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.relevant_excerpt:
Davis based his case against Wonderland on two theories: that the described system in use in and about the crosswalk for getting the crowd over the highway was intrinsically inadequate and contributed to the accident, and Wonderland should and could have done better; and that the officer on the particular occasion behaved negligently and Wonderland was responsible for the consequences.

… The fact is that Wonderland voluntarily undertook the task and was thus cast with a duty to exercise due care in carrying it out.

Coughlin v. Pitney, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 94.raw_text: Coughlin v. Pitney, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 942 (1996)
Coughlin v. Pitney, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 94.proposition: Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Relevant Massachusetts authorities establishing Defendant’s liability include:
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The quoted text is a dissent focused on lack of causation, but it occurs in a case where the majority opinion (not reproduced here) expressly recognized that the college owed a duty of reasonable care to protect resident students against foreseeable criminal acts and upheld liability based on negligent security. Thus, Mullins v. Pine Manor College is, overall, a leading Massachusetts authority establishing a defendant college’s potential liability for a student’s injuries from third‑party crime, even though the excerpt itself argues against finding proximate cause.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award prejudgment and postjudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
